title: Former TPG Executive William McGlashan Jr. to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Case
sub_head: McGlashan will admit to involvement in testing scheme, but not athletic bribery conspiracy; plea deal calls for three months in prison
body:
Former TPG executive William McGlashan Jr. has agreed to plead guilty for his role in the Varsity Blues college admissions scandal, heading off a trial that was slated to begin later this year.
Mr. McGlashan is former managing partner of TPG Growth and co-founder of the Rise Fund, one of the highest-profile defendants in the sprawling criminal case. He agreed to plead guilty on Friday to one count of aiding and abetting wire fraud and honest services wire fraud, according to a plea agreement filed in Boston federal court.
Mr. McGlashan was accused in March 2019 alongside dozens of other parents, a corrupt college counselor, athletic coaches and others of participating in a scheme to fraudulently get teenagers into highly selective colleges.
Prosecutors said Mr. McGlashan paid $50,000 to college counselor William “Rick” Singer to arrange for a proctor to fix his son’s wrong answers on the ACT. He was also accused of pursuing a plan to channel bribes through a college counselor to slot the boy in as a recruited athlete at the University of Southern California.
Under the terms of the plea deal, prosecutors will recommend he receive a three-month prison sentence and pay a $250,000 fine. Other parents who have been sentenced in the case received sentences ranging from probation to nine months in prison.
